translated: Jātaka
The Book of the Elevens🔽The Chapter on Mother’s Keeper
The Jātaka of Mother’s Keeper
“Because of the absence of that nāga,
The sallakī and kuṭajā trees have grown;
The kuruvinda and karavīra trees, and the bhisasāmā,
And the kaṇikāra trees have blossomed in the wind.
Some goldsmiths,
Are feeding the nāga king with morsels;
Where the king or prince
Will put on armor without fear.”
“Take the morsel, nāga,
Don’t be a miser, nāga;
There are many royal duties,
Those you will do, nāga.”
“Surely that poor woman,
Blind and helpless,
Stumbles with her foot on a stump,
And falls on a rocky slope.”

analyzed: kā nu te sā mahā nāga
translated: “What is that to you, great nāga,
Blind and helpless,
Stumbles with her foot on a stump,
And falls on a rocky slope?”
“That is my mother, great king,
Blind and helpless,
Stumbles with her foot on a stump,
And falls on a rocky slope.”
“Release that great nāga,
Who is supporting his mother;
The elephant will meet his mother,
together with all his relatives.”
“The elephant is freed from his bonds,
the elephant has taken his freedom;
Having rested for a moment,
he has gone to the mountain.
Then he went to the lotus pond,
the cool one frequented by elephants;
Having scooped up water with his trunk,
he sprinkled his mother.”
“Who is this unrighteous god,
who rains at the wrong time?
My son, my offspring, has gone,
who was my attendant.”
“Rise up, mother, why do you lie down?
Your son has come to you.
I am freed by the King of Kāsi,
by the famous King Videha.”
“Long live that king,
the increaser of the Kāsi kingdom;
Who has freed my son,
who always respects the elders.”
The Jātaka of the Mother’s Provider, the first.
